section.title: Setting up 3PAR
section.p: The following section outlines the steps you need to follow in order to configure a Virtual File Server and a share for use by the Kubernetes NFS provisioner.
Create a virtual file server (VFS):

ol.li:
In the General section, as shown in , specify a name, in this instance gab_vfs3par
Create Virtual File Server - General

In the Storage Allocation Settings section, as shown in , set the Provisioning to Thin Provisioned, select an appropriate CPG, in this instance FC_r1, and set the size, for example, 1 terabyte.
Create Virtual File Server - Storage Allocation Settings

Add a virtual IP address as shown in .
Create Virtual File Server - Add Virtual IP Address

section.p: These steps result in a Virtual File Server shown in .
Create a File Store:

ol.li:
In the General section, as shown in , specify a name, in this instance gab_filestore3par, and select the Virtual File Server that you just created.
Create File Store - General

Use the default Security settings, as shown in .
Create File Store - Security

section.p: These steps result in the File Store shown in .
Create a File Share:

ol.li:
In the General section of the Create File Share dialog, shown , set the share type to NFS Share and set a share name, for example, gab_fileshare3par
Create File Share - General

In the Share Path section, select the virtual file server and file store that you created earlier, as shown in
Create File Share - Share Path

In the Additional Settings section, set the Permission to Read/Write allowed and the Privilege to root squashing is off (no root squash) as shown in
Create File Share - Share Path

section.title: Verification
section.p: Ensure that your environment satisfies the prerequisites as described in and then run the playbook:
Running the command kubectl get sc will show the storage class named nfs:
section.codeblock: # kubectl get sc NAME PROVISIONER AGE nfs-3par hpe.com/nfs-3par 5m
section.p: Create a temporary file /tmp/pvc-3par.yml for a persistent volume claim (PVC) named nfs-3par-test with a storage class of nfs-3par
section.codeblock: # cat /tmp/pvc.yml <<EOF --- kind: PersistentVolumeClaim apiVersion: v1 metadata: name: nfs-3par-test annotations: volume.beta.kubernetes.io/storage-class: "nfs-3par" spec: accessModes: - ReadWriteMany resources: requests: storage: 100Mi EOF
section.p: Create the PVC resource by running kubectl apply on this file.
Verify that the corresponding persistent volume (PV) was created at the same time.
section.codeblock: # kubectl get pv NAME CAPACITY ACCESS MODES RECLAIM POLICY STATUS CLAIM STORAGECLASS REASON AGE pvc-5dd91d9b-a520-11e8-975d-0242ac110010 100Mi RWX Delete Bound default/nfs-3par-test nfs-3par 58s
section.p: Define a pod that will mount the persistent volume through using the persistent volume claim. The persistent volume is mounted under /tmp/foo.
section.codeblock: cat /tmp/pod.yml <<EOF apiVersion: apps/v1beta2 kind: Deployment metadata: name: nfs-3par-pod spec: selector: matchLabels: app: nfs-3par-pod replicas: 1 template: metadata: labels: app: nfs-3par-pod spec: volumes: - name: pod-data persistentVolumeClaim: claimName: nfs-3par-test containers: - name: nfs-3par-pod command: - sh - -c - while true; do sleep 1; done image: radial/busyboxplus:curl volumeMounts: - mountPath: /tmp/foo name: pod-data EOF
section.p: Create the pod resource by running kubectl apply on the file.
Retrieve the pod ID and then execute a command in the pod to create a test file on the persistent volume. The file is named /tmp/foo/bar.txt and contains the string hello.
section.codeblock: # pod=$(kubectl get pod | awk '/nfs-3par-pod-/ {print $1}') # kubectl exec -it $pod -- sh -c "echo hello >/tmp/foo/bar.txt"
section.p: Check that the file was written correctly:
Now delete the deployment associated with the pod.
section.codeblock:
# kubectl get deploy nfs-3par-pod NAME DESIRED CURRENT UP-TO-DATE AVAILABLE AGE nfs-3par-pod 1 1 1 1 28m
# kubectl delete deploy nfs-3par-pod deployment.extensions "nfs-3par-pod" deleted
section.p: Wait until the status is no longer Terminating and the pod is deleted.
section.codeblock: kubectl get pod NAME READY STATUS RESTARTS AGE nfs-3par-pod-5c4896699d-zfq9n 1/1 Terminating 0 28m
section.p: Re-create the pod as before, by running kubectl apply on the file /tmp/pod-3par.yml.
Retrieve the pod id:
section.codeblock:
# pod=$(kubectl get pod | awk '/nfs-3par-pod-/ {print $1} ')
# echo $pod nfs-3par-pod-5c4896699d-kl6bw
# kubectl get pod NAME READY STATUS RESTARTS AGE nfs-3par-pod-5c4896699d-kl6bw 1/1 Running 0 38s
section.p: Connect to the new pod, and retrieve the contents of the file you created previously.
